comment: Yes. It's true that you have 3 tests that make up 90% of the grade, but if you attend the class, read the textbook, and ask questions, you have nothing to worry about. This was a very laid-back class, and she explains the different philosophies in a coherent way. Just make sure you read the essay prompts carefully, and don't half-measure your essay
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: This woman does not put in grades. I once emailed her asking her to put my grades into the grade portal and she just straight up said she doesn't use it. I have no clue if I'm passing or failing and we only have two weeks left. Only good thing is attendance isn't mandatory especially when she spends half the lecture coughing up a lung.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Graded by few things

comment: Absolutely terrible. Only had three essays as assignments and she grades super harsh. Gives little to no feedback and offers no extra credit. Never got my grades put in the entire semester. Literally had to check Owl Express. DO NOT TAKE HER
rating_tags: Tough grader--Graded by few things

comment: Horrible at grading, as in, she takes forever to grade things, as well as being very unclear and passive-aggressive in the grading. Seems to not care about what the person actually thinks, and actively penalizes her students for having an opinion different than hers when it comes to the three essays, which comprise 90 percent of the total grade.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Only grades in this class are three essays. She gives awful or no feedback on essays. Feedback consists of things like "no", "nope" etc. Instead of explaining what the issue is. Assuming you any feedback... on one of my essays I got nothing. She also marked wrong things in my essays she said were correct in her lectures. Awful professor, stay away.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Weirdest class I've ever taken. You will have to read a ton from the book but that should be normal for philosophy. Grades in this class consist of three essays (3-4 pages). She is the slowest at grading essays out of any teacher I've had. I had to submit my final (aka essay 3) before I even got feedback or a grade on my second essay.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: I enjoyed the lectures and open discussion on the readings we did but each week it was a lot of reading and assignments on the readings that were pretty heavy. There are three essays and an overall participation grade and that is all she grades by. The essays were so hard and she barely gave any feedback and it was hard to tell what you did wrong.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Honestly the worst professor Ive ever had. Lectures are pointless and its all about what she wants to hear, not what you actually think. Grades super passive aggressively. AVOID AT ALL COSTS. I do not reckon her for anyone. Seriously do not take her class
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: I wouldn't recommend this professor to anyone. If you're expecting to get grades back you'll be disappointed b/c she only graded 1 assignment before Spring Break & at the end of the break she only graded the 1st essay when she already had 4 other assignments to grade. Classes are pointless since you read material first then go over. Just avoid her.
rating_tags: So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Rouse is a good professor and as long as you go to class and pay attention and ask questions if you need to, you should be fine. She doesnt grade things super fast and doesnt give a lot of feedback, but if you ask her personally she will help you. there is a lot of reading, but such is philosophy
rating_tags: Respected--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Not very good with feedback essays. Each class was just her trying to explain what the previous reading was. The essays never seemed to relate to what she talked about in class so you really have to dig and think about the essays.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Hardest class ive taken at KSU. She is such a hard grader but gives passive aggressive feedback on the essays and doesnt make it clear on how to improve for the next essay. The class is heavily lectured for no reason and she makes the class unnecessarily difficult. I didnt watch her lectures. I taught myself through youtube videos
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: Most of the class will be her talking, no powerpoints, and small hard to read handwriting. She has a soft quiet voice so if you aren't a morning person I suggest you don't take her class early because it will be easy to fall asleep. The textbook is extremely hard to read and does not give a lot of feedback on essays.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: I'd like to start by saying that she wasn't particularly awful, just irritating. She doesn't post grades, for one. For two, she has six papers you'll write, which isn't really a big deal, and is very picky as to what she wants in your paper. I tried to improve with each paper, but each was met with foggy feedback and an clueless feeling.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: If you are just taking it for credit, I highly don't recommend taking this class. If you are majoring in philosophy then it might be okay. The number of reading assignments is exhausting.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: I actually enjoyed her lectures they were simple and almost relaxing however the essays killed me. Not only were they difficult in context but she would give close to zero feedback leaving you clueless on how to improve she would write like one or two comments like huh? Or what? And then boom, you got a C on the paper.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Rouse has a very specific teaching style - she only uses the white board during lecture. If you are someone who has trouble focusing when a class is boring, don't take her. There are only 3 papers and some homework assignments which count for participation. She's a really tough grader (like, wants absolute perfection) on papers
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: As someone who actually cares about their general education courses, this one wasn't too bad. You have a lot of reading analysis assignments to do, but they really help whenever it comes to writing essays. You have 3 essay exams per semester, and EACH count for 30% of your grade. The other 10% comes from your participation (ex: reading analysis).
rating_tags: Respected--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: She's nice enough if you participate and know how to spew philosophical nonsense back to her in your essays, but I am lost in every single class I go to. Her lectures are impossible to follow, the textbook makes no sense, and 70% of the class is her asking questions and all of us staring back at her like "What is this lady on about?"
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Read the material, and give serious thought to your analyses. Tests are based on both lectures and readings, so if you go to class, take notes, and read the material, you'll do just fine.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Inspirational--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Rouse is a really sweet lady, but its the end of finals and I still have NO idea what my grade is. She has given tons of reading analysis assignments and has not posted a grade for any of them. I felt like I didnt need to go in for over half of the classes. Also the homework was fairly unorganized and I barely know when things were due.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I was one of the only kids in class that participated, so I don't know how the other students did, but for me this was super easy. Prep yourself a little on the philosophers before class and look up the reading passages online and you'll never look at this book. If you're taking this because you want to major in philosophy however, look elsewhere
Good teacher but a little hard to please when it comes to papers, fairly generous with partial credit on exams.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read

comment: She could use a lot of work in lecturing (very hard to follow). She will shut you down if you pose an argument to the information presented by the various philosophers. She uses simple-minded concepts that don't hold up to the most basic scrutiny. After my rant, I will turn to the more positive sides; she gives participation credit & no homework.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: I asked her about my grade on one pf my papers and she told me "You're just not a philosopher". Honestly, rewrite her opinion back to her in your papers and you'll be golden.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: As a black and white thinker philosophy isn't really my favorite topic, despite that my experience with the class was alright. The class is graded by 3 essays and a few participation grades. Shes a lenient  grader and if she sees you understand the topic shell grade you well. The lectures are hit or miss, interesting wise. overall a decent class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Dr. Rouse knows her material and gets her point across very well. The tests were essay that you could do at home and had a due date into dropbox.  The assignments were helpful in preparing for the tests. I would take this professor again in a heartbeat. Good upper level elective, especially if you like philosophy.

I had Dr. Rouse for American Philosophy during my last semester at KSU. While she seemed very adapt at generating class discussion, I don't believe she truly knows how to lecture. Her discussions were often one sided. She was not clear on what the required readings were. Often the reading material was very mundane and boring. This was not ideal!

I've taken Dr. Rouse twice, and I would do so again. She's not a conventional lecturer, preferring to teach via Q&A sessions (she asks, you answer), but if you can write a decent paper you should make an easy A. Exams are take-home essays. She does come across as a know-it-all sometimes, but she was certainly not "hostile" to me or to anyone else.

shes awful, makes dramatically errors speaking and writing in class then complains about students doing the same. says that you miss the point in a paper then says she didn't read those sections that clearly when someone says something in class. worst teacher at an others great school.

Grades are: 4 reading summaries, and 3 exams. If you show that you READ the material, then making at least a B on the summaries is easy. Two of the four exams were online, therefore good exam clarity. Bottom line: if you show that you understand the main points of the material, and can write a college level paper, then you will do well in 3020
Never gets to a point.  Makes absolutely no sense in majority of discussions.

Rouse is pretty amusing, & I enjoyed her teaching style. She's not the most exciting professor, but I learned quite a bit from her. My only complaint concerns her grading system: I received grades ranging from As to Cs, and have no idea why I received them. Some papers received no comments or tips for improvement, & asking her didn't help.

I didn't care for her condescending personality nor her redundant, interrogative style of teaching. Attendance policy (you can only miss two classes) was ridiculous, especially since nothing we learned was particularly relevant. She also thinks she knows everything about metro Atlanta and she's not even from the area.

Dr. Rouse is a great professor, but her teaching style is different. Rather than just lecturing, she will usually ask the class a series of questions and whatever answers she receives she "teaches" the material by using those answers. This makes it difficult to take notes because you never know what is important and what's not.

Try your best to avoid this professor. She grades your papers harshly and she is a nightmare to listen to. She will often not reach her point or will spend 3/4 of the class getting to it. Avoid her if you can.

This teacher is a complete space cadet.  The syllabus changes from minute to minute.  She goes completely off topic, to topics not even relevant for the exams.  Lectures are horribly boring.  Grades papers hard.  Exams are open book and all essay but you can choose from several questions to answer.  Takes forever to get grades back
Not as cocky as most of the Philosophy professor's at KSU. I've enjoyed her class--she doesn't bore you to death and she grades fairly.

Rouse is very knowledgeable on her subject and does her best to make dry readings interesting and relative. Class participation is a must to stay focused and understand the material. Bringing a laptop to wiki other philosophers saved me. She assumes you have a detailed background on ancient philosophers.

Dr. Rouse is a difficult teacher in terms of class. I found a nice niche behind a support beam and played on the internet mostly. Read your books, and think about how you can tie in liberalism into philosophy and you should do fine.

Rouse knows her material. You can be sure that you will either come out of this class with a fairly thorough knowledge of the material, or a failing grade.there is no "A for effort" here. She grades tough, is very opinionated, and teaches using socratic method (throwing questions back at you instead of really answering.) Worth taking,but hard.

I took Dr. Rouse three times and enjoyed the class even when it wasn't material that I cared about and even when I wasn't doing well. Sometimes the concepts she teaches are very iffy; it's not her fault. If it's incomprehensible, it's because of the thinker - not Dr. Rouse. If you show that you care, she'll do everything in her power to help you.

ROUSE does not know how to communicate the material; poorly organized; attacks any and all questions; all "clarifications" end up obfuscating things even more. No real grading policy, just a vague notion of her likes and dislikes. She clearly didn't bother to read my essays with any level of attention. Condescending. Annoying b/c she is uniformed..

If this is a required class for you, she is the only professor that teaches it. Going to class was useless. Her lectures have no direction and she seemed to rebuff any comments made by the students. If you asked her to clarify something, the explanation was not clear at all. The books for class are also hard to comprehend sometimes. Good luck
I'm not going to suggest that this class is easy. However if you have an interest in philosophy and American history, you'll be alright. Learn the material!
SO HARD! this class is rediculous! the professor helped but the course in general is pointless. If you want to take it, and want to be confused at the end, take her. If not...take communications!

Let me just say, I'm transferring to pursue a philosophy major, and though the material covered in class was great, the presentation, interest, and ambiguous grading by Dr. Rouse made the class mediocre at best. I would not recommend this as an elective. (Oh yeah, she twice forgot extra credit test questions promised for class attendance)
American Philosophy. 6 3-page summaries about reading, one oral presentation (easy), and 3 exams.  Hard to get an A because, well, it's philosophy.
Dr. Rouse I disagreed with on Kant, Mill, Nietzche, however, an excellent teacher who made the subject interesting. Thank you Dr. R.
Unusual class for today -- thinking outside the box is required to do well.

Make sure you take good notes and be prepared for tests. Best thing to do is to take main topics and look up on internet to best understand things, thats the only way I really understood anything. She is not very clear on things and seems to get off of subject at times.  Class is boring.

History majors may find this class boring. Dr. Rouse is nice and she tries to make topic clear, but for someone not in tune with philosopy, this class is boring and all you can do is sit and wonder..WHO THE HECK COMES UP WITH THIS STUFF??!!!You have to do your own research to get the basics and understand the readings.

She is engaging during lecture, but she makes the material seem more complicated than it actually is.  Take really good notes and be prepared to do a lot of reading.  Overall, the content is interesting, but not amazingly straight forward.

Class is very boring and the litature is uninteresting.  The summaries are pointless and waste of time and are graded as if it was a detailed analysis, but if you write an analysis you are penalized.  The test are easy just know the main points and write the essay's. Overall all its a boring and useless class with poor teaching.
The way she engages students is great.  It's easy to participate in classes, and she gives very helpful paper comments & lots of encouragemnt.  She's also quite professionally active, which is cool.

The text sucks, but Dr. Rouse is cool.  I passed notes all day with the cute girl next to me and still got a B!  Homework is ungraded and just "checked' that you did it!  However, she does have a monotone voice that will lull you to sleep, so no morn

It is difficult to get more than a B on her essays, I suggest not taking this class early in the morning as she has a very monotone way of speaking that will lull you to sleep if you are tired. A good teacher, my only issue with the course is the text.

Picky, but very nice.  Take good notes, pay attention in class, ask questions if you don't understand, do the extra credit (its well worth it) and read the material and you should do well in the class.
Don`t show up if you aren`t ready to learn.
Picky, but nice. Read your stuff and do your questions.
